posts.cooked:
Recently I have made efforts to spend less time on my phone and enjoy the world around me more. Realistically I can‚Äôt fully switch away from a smartphone (2FA, banking), but the idea to switch to something like a Light Phone as a daily driver is appealing.

The only downside though: you can‚Äôt run Signal on it. From their FAQ:

It may also be possible to offer alternative messaging platforms like Signal, Whatsapp, Telegram etc. in the future, but we don‚Äôt currently have plans or a timeline for that functionality.

I think it would be great if Signal could team up with a company like this. I think that there is a certain degree of overlap between the mission of Signal and Light Phone in the sense that they want to be functional without falling into the rabbit hole that many corporations want to suck their users into. Neither wants to engage users more with their product than what users choose for themselves rather than what they‚Äôre tricked into.

What do you guys think? Would Signal on something like the Light Phone a viable idea?

thelightphone.com

The Light Phone

Light is a radically different technology company. We design beautiful tools that respect and empower our users and our first product is The Light Phone.
Interesting. Had a check on compatibility, had to enter my country (Germany) and they told me that it is not compatible (yet) with it. I am out

Regarding less screen time: I‚Äôve found focus mode and app timers on my S23U to be invaluable. If I know I have a limited amount of time or a specific window of time to use a set of apps, I‚Äôm much more thoughtful about when and how I spend that time.

Avitus:

This one explicitly calls out Signal compatibility/Signal is already installed under the rebranded ‚ÄúPigeon‚Äù name

This is really awesome! It sounds like the perfect phone to give to your child so that they can keep in touch while they‚Äôre out. But I wonder how their Signal client is being maintained?

Avitus:

Regarding less screen time: I‚Äôve found focus mode and app timers on my S23U to be invaluable. If I know I have a limited amount of time or a specific window of time to use a set of apps, I‚Äôm much more thoughtful about when and how I spend that time.

Same here, I put a hard cap on my browser allowance per day. And lately I have been tossing my phone out of sight, that really helps as well.

Both of those look quite interesting.

Another tip on reducing app usage is to select a launcher that lets you hide apps or makes it more difficult to open them in some other way.

found focus mode and app timers

i‚Äôve found this extremely valuable as well. all my ‚Äúsocial media‚Äù type apps are paused during my working hours and I use the bedtime mode to make it easier to disengage regardless of what‚Äôs going on at 23:00

posts.cooked: For sure! Restricting apps during work hours has really reduced distractions.

posts.name: Clayton Burns
posts.cooked:
TeeJay82:

This is really awesome! It sounds like the perfect phone to give to your child so that they can keep in touch while they‚Äôre out. But I wonder how their Signal client is being maintained?

I have a MP02, and it is great! Pigeon appears to be a wrapper on the Signal client. You can receive pics, videos, reactions, etc. but can only send text (there‚Äôs no camera, so not an issue). But, no camera means no linked devices. It does support manually entering the information to link devices, but it usually expires before the connection completes.
the little i read was that pigeon was pretty unreliable. how open and consistent is their development?

posts.name: Clayton Burns
posts.cooked:
I have had no problems with it when it comes to basic messaging and audio calls. I have noticed that the GitHub page hasn‚Äôt been updated in some time, but I have gotten two Pigeon updates since the last GitHub update, so it‚Äôs not abandoned by any means.

I have had other issues with the phone. The LTE bands are limited, so connectivity in some areas can be rough. Battery life when used heavily is not great. Wi-Fi tends to disconnect and refuse to auto connect. There‚Äôs also usability problems, though the point of the phone is to be simple and discourage use, so I don‚Äôt really mind. Entering contacts is tedious, no copy and paste, T9 typing could be better with it‚Äôs autocorrect, and parts of the interface are less than intuitive.

All that said, it‚Äôs my vacation phone, and serves that purpose perfectly.
With which carrier are you able to use it?

posts.name: Clayton Burns
posts.cooked: My carrier is Mint Mobile (T-Mobile MVNO). They tend to have a better experience with global phone variants, so definitely check the LTE bands vs your carrier.
